title.narrative: Enhancing Belize’s capacity to adapt to Climate Change

description.narrative: Global Climate Change Alliance Belize: Enhancing Belize’s capacity to adapt to Climate Change

The proposed initiative targets directly climate change governance structures, positioning the Government of Belize to effectively plan for and manage the effects of climate change on Belize’s Development.
independent political entity

Increased of the capacity of the government and civil society to take informed action on climate change Level of National Adaptive Capacity level determined by: • Number of administrative areas where CC capacity building results in more effective use of existing budgets for activities that reduce disaster risk and enhance adaptive capacity • Extent to which government plans and budgets have been modified to reflect CC evidence generated • Level of community and non-state stakeholder engagement.
-Existence of literature database -National Circumstance document updated -Increased knowledge of good practices on increasing resilience to CC –to – water related risks -Number of project beneficiaries receiving training in implementation of specific adaptation measures or decision-support tools -Capacity to assess, monitor, predict and interpret climate change – to-sector related risks in Belize -Improved development conditions in relation to climate change stressors

comment.narrative:
Belize is highly vulnerable to climate change, with low capacity to adapt. Models of future climate change suggest that The temperature in Belize is rising faster than the global average. The rate of increase in Belize for the past 40 years has been 0.40 per decade along the coast and 0.45 in the interior, exceeding both the global 50-year and 25-year trends. The baseline project consists of strengthening capacity at several levels to undertake integrated climate change adaptation/ mitigation planning and integrated water resource management planning
Current situation is one in which water sector governance mandates are scattered across multiple ministries with very little coordination linkage. This presents difficulties in planning for and managing the sustainable use of the resource commonly resulting in duplication of efforts and confusion as to assigned roles and responsibilities
National authorities agree on the need for concentration of efforts on Climate change adaptation and Belize like most SIDS is extremely vulnerable to the effects of climate change climate variation. Belize’s vulnerability is exacerbated on its dependence on its natural resources base to drive its economic development.
Climate change interventions remained largely within the ex-Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment and the topic is not yet treated as a cross cutting theme impacting national development. This has resulted in a concentration of capacities for addressing climate change and climate change knowledge resources allowing the continued classifying of climate change as an environmental issue.
Project is in Operational and Financial Closure.

description.narrative: OAK funding to be re-granted as co-financing to local COMPACT projects. Programme focuses on local stakeholders of the Belize Barrier Reef Complex.
OAK SGP
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

NSC approves four (4) Small Grants to Civil Society Organizations to implement projects by December 2015 in support of thematic area #1.
NSC approves four (4) Small Grants to Civil Society Organizations to implement projects under COMPACT`s Thematic area # 2 by December 2015.
NSC approves four (4) Small Grants to Civil Society Organizations to implement projects under COMPACT`s Thematic area # 3 by December 2015.

comment.narrative: Projects will be awarded under the three COMPACT Thematic Areas: #1: “Expand Sustainable Livelihood Options” #2. “Promote the Protection, Conservation and Sustainable Use of Resources” #3: “Develop and Enhance, Management Capacities of Stakeholders that Impact the Belize Barrier Reef Reserve System World Heritage Site”
Partnership with six (6) Community Based Organizations implementing Community Landscape/Seascape Conservation Management Approach in Operational Phase 6.

Targeted and strategic partnership with grantee partners implementing GEF SGP/Oak resources. Improved Fisheries Management and Protected Areas Management and compliance with regulations by resource users. Enhanced grantmaker + role and leveraging of non-GEF resources at project and program level. Enhanced support for manage access role out and Indigenous Community Conserved Areas Initiative. Integration of the Social and Environmental Standards and Accountability in CPS development process and grant selection criteria.
Enhanced alternative livelihood opportunities for marginalized fisherfolk, increase in participation and representation of fishers in national dialogue platforms influencing policy change and advocating for equality.

title.narrative: Belize Chemicals and Waste Management Project

description.narrative: The project aims to assist the country in implementing its relevant obligations under the Stockholm Convention to reduce the releases of Unintentional POPs emissions and to build country’s capacity to manage chemicals and waste.

title.narrative: Belize Chemicals and Waste Management Project

description.narrative: The project aims to assist the country in implementing its relevant obligations under the Stockholm Convention to reduce the releases of Unintentional POPs emissions and to build country’s capacity to manage chemicals and waste.
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

*Chemicals Bill legally adopted and in force. *Industrial and Consumer Chemicals Regulations and PCBs guidelines are adopted. *Successful Export of export and disposal of existing POPS waste *Green Harvesting is included as a requirement for premium price schemes * M& E and adpative management are applied to project in response to needs, mid-term evaluation findings with lessons learned extracted.

comment.narrative:
Baseline presented as per project logframe:
*Draft National Integrated Chemicals Management Bill developed *No specific chemicals and waste regulations or draft exist. *21 Tonnes of DDT and associated waste are packed for dipsosal and 7 Tonnes of PCB contaminated waste are in barrels at a private entity * Green Harvested can does not fetch a higher price * No monitoring and Evaluation system no evaluation of project outpu and outcomes are in place
Capacity building undertaken and disposal contract awarded. Transfer center built and operational Monitoring and Evaluation system developed during first year.

At the end of Q3 the transfer station is in its final stage of completion in line with the reduction of UPOPS releases from uncontrolled, open burning of waste. The verification of existing inventory in country is in the process of being finalized to ensure disposal of existing waste.
Chemical Bill legally in force Successful export disposal of existing POPs waste Green Harvesting of Sugar Cane is practiced among small holding farmers

title.narrative: Capacity-building for sustaimnable Natural Resource Mgmt

description.narrative: To enhance Belize’s institutional and organizational capacities for sustainable natural resource management for the effective leveraging of finances to meet Rio Convention Objectives.

title.narrative: Capacity Building for Sustainable Natural Resource Management PRODOC

description.narrative: The goal of this project is for Belize to meet and sustain Rio Convention obligations through a more holistic and cost-effective approach of environmental and nat. resource mgmt for shared national development and global environmental priorities.
capital of a political entity
policy, planning and administration

 A comprehensive set of environmental natural resource and sustainable development indicators are developed and integrated into a National Sustainable Development Strategy  Uniform data collection methods  Hardware and software for improved data/information management and monitoring systems are identified and installed with training provided to technical staff.  Environmental We based portal is structured, beta-tested and launched  Natural Resource Valuation tools are integrated into key decision making processes  A set of SEA implementation guidelines and policy developed  Bill to integrate NRV into planning and development processes with full input from stakeholders  Resource mobilization strategy for the financial sustainability of global environment is developed  Assessment of a capacity needs assessment to prepare low carbon development strategies

comment.narrative:  Lack of indicators for environmental Monitoring and natural resource management  Data is not regularly collected or analyzed in a manner consistent with international standards or Rio Convention obligations  Lack of national capacities needed to generate good, reliable data for real time monitoring of environmental trends  Environmental data is not easily accessible from one centralized source  Natural Resource Valuation guidelines are not widely known or understood among planers and decision makers  The SEA process in Belize does not account for true value of natural resources  Poorly defined institutional structures and mandates relating to the collection management and sharing of data and information relevant to environmental protection, risk reduction and development planning  Weak compliance with existing legislation due to limitations in national capacities for monitoring and enforcement and inadequate financing for environmental management Lack of institutional capacities in terms of technical knowledge, personnel, and financial resources to participate in evidence based environmental management and development planning limits Belize’s ability to develop low carbon strategies.

Carry out institutional analysis of data needs and indicators Detail a concrete set of environmental, natural resource, and sustainable development indicators Form expert sub-committee under NEAC on data collection standards and quality assurance Assess methodologies with attention to harmonization and metrics, relevance, validity, and quality Strengthen technological and technical capacities to create data and information for monitoring Integrate natural resource valuation tools into key decision-making processes Conduct expert review of SEA process to identify best practices and lessons learned Convene sensitization workshops to raise stakeholder awareness of SEA process

Project implementation was delayed in 2015, the country underwent general elections in the latter part of 2015. Even though there was not a change in administration, there was a change in the configuration of Ministries and Departments. There were new players and leads which resulted in a slight delay to project implementation.

A comprehensive set of environmental natural resource and sustainable development indicators are developed and integrated into a National Sustainable Development Strategy
Hardware and software for improved data/information management and monitoring systems are identified and installed with training provided to technical staff.
An Environmental Web based portal is structured, beta-tested and launched
A set of SEA implementation guidelines and policy developed and a Bill to integrate NRV into planning and development processes with full input from stakeholders  An Assessment of a capacity needs assessment to prepare low carbon development strategies
